title: SH vs CH Pronunciation: A Complete Guide
excerpt: Do you confuse 'shoes' with 'choose'? Learn the key difference between /ʃ/ and /tʃ/ sounds in English with audio examples and practice words.
author: BeCa

content.text: SH vs CH: Master the Difference Between /ʃ/ and /tʃ/

Mixing up the SH and CH sounds is one of the most common pronunciation challenges for English learners. Have you ever said 'shoes' when you meant 'choose', or 'ship' instead of 'chip'? You're not alone! The good news is that there's one simple difference between these two sounds, and once you understand it, you'll never confuse them again.

content.label: The SH Sound
content.description: The /ʃ/ sound is a continuous fricative. This means air flows smoothly and without interruption through a narrow gap between your tongue and the roof of your mouth. You can hold this sound for as long as you have breath: 'shhhhhh'. Think of it as the sound you make when telling someone to be quiet.
how_to_produce: Place the tip of your tongue close to the roof of your mouth, just behind the ridge.
Shape your lips into a slight rounded position.
Push air out continuously through the narrow gap.
Your vocal cords should NOT vibrate (it's a voiceless sound).
Key test: you can stretch this sound indefinitely — 'shhhhhhhh'.

content.label: The CH Sound
content.description: The /tʃ/ sound is an explosive affricate. It starts with a brief stop (like a /t/) followed by a quick release of the /ʃ/ sound. Unlike SH, you CANNOT hold this sound — it's a short burst of air. Think of it as a sneeze: 'ch!'.
how_to_produce: Press the tip of your tongue firmly against the ridge behind your upper teeth.
Build up a small amount of air pressure behind your tongue.
Release the tongue quickly, letting the air burst out.
Your vocal cords should NOT vibrate (it's also voiceless).
Key test: you CANNOT stretch this sound — it's always a quick burst.

content.text: /ʃ/ is CONTINUOUS (like a breeze) — /tʃ/ is EXPLOSIVE (like a pop). If you can hold the sound, it's SH. If it comes out as a quick burst, it's CH. That's the entire difference: SH flows, CH pops.
Minimal Pairs: Practice Hearing the Difference
Minimal pairs are words that differ by only one sound. Practicing these pairs trains your ear and mouth to distinguish and produce each sound correctly.

cards.example: I take a shower every morning.
Push the door to open it.
Do you want sugar in your tea?
I love cheese on my pizza.
Can you change this for me?

items: Don't add a /t/ before the SH sound. 'Ship' is NOT 'tchip' — keep SH smooth and continuous.
Don't stretch the CH sound. 'Chip' should be a quick burst, not 'shhhip'.
Watch out for spelling traps! Words like 'machine' (/məʃiːn/) use SH despite having 'ch' in the spelling.
Practice in front of a mirror: for CH, you should see a brief stop as your tongue presses up, then a quick release.
Record yourself saying minimal pairs and compare. Can you hear the continuous vs. explosive difference?

sentences.text: She chose cheap shoes from the shop.
The chef showed us a special chocolate dish.
Charlie washed his shirt before the championship.
Shall we watch the show or choose a different channel?

points: /ʃ/ (SH) = continuous airflow, like a gentle breeze. You can hold it: 'shhhh'.
/tʃ/ (CH) = explosive burst, like a quick pop. You cannot hold it: 'ch!'.
Both sounds are voiceless (no vibration in your throat).
The tongue position is nearly the same — the only difference is whether air flows continuously or is briefly stopped then released.
This is a common challenge for speakers of Spanish, French, Japanese, Korean, and many other languages. With practice, the distinction becomes natural!
